Turbines can't run on saturated steam, as the steam would immediately condense as it gives up energy across the turbine stages. Turbines don't like water. From what I remember there were more or less 3 reasons I remember as to why this isn't used as much compared to PV, despite it being able to fix one of the most important problems with renewables: intermittency.

These problems are:
1) Cost: CSP costs around 3-4 times what PV costs, so that immediately isn't really great. If we can get storage costs low enough, PV+storage is also more interesting.
2) Geographical limitation: You can't just place these plants everywhere, the efficiency reduces a lot depending on the available sunlight. And ofcourse you need space and lots of it. With PV you can if need be place it in smaller units in a same location to avoid obstacles, elevation differences etc. aren't that much of a problem, with CSP this can be more of a problem. Another problem here is that CSP isn't usually located close to the main energy users, so you possibly need to install connection wires etc too. With PV you can place them on the roofs, car parks, nearby fields, ... limiting these kind of connection costs.
3) Water usage: These mirrors need to be kept clean. This often requires water use to do so. The problem is that these systems usually are in more arid places where water is more valuable. Ofcourse you might have ways to get around this, but they will usually be less effective or more costly. This was for example one of the controversies with CSP plants in Morocco that were subsidies by the EU, I believe.

Does CSP has a place in the grid mix? Yes, I think they definitely will play a role. Are they likely to become one of the main sources/compete with PV? Doubtfull. They might be usefull for energy intensive industries that could possibly be build around them and then either you use their storage to keep these industries going 24/7 or it is used to help balance the grid in the evening/at night.

If you were to ignore things like costs, political stability (for example northern Africa region), ... , CSP would likely be the best source to get us fully renewable. in fact they are probably one of the only renewable sources that could completely on its own get us to 100% renewable; No battery storage, no PV, wind, hydro, ... needed, just CSP. But it would be expensive and you'd need to use very long connections and the losses that go with it.

I believe you might have misspoken and mentioned saturated steam when you meant superheated steam. You never send saturated steam to a turbine or even old-style steam locomotive cylinders. If you were to send saturated steam through the pipes it would expand in the turbine or steam cylinder, it would cool and partially condense into zillions of tiny droplets that act like pellets, blasting over the turbine blades, chipping away material in no time at all. In old locomotives, the problem with that condensation is that water does not compress as steam does so, at the end of its run, the pistons would press against non-compressible water, damaging all the mechanism. That is why steam engines take quite long to start, you have to heat up all the steam circuit, valves and mechanisms so that at no point steam will cool down enough to condense into water. What you do, as the diagram seen in your video at 2:05 shows, you superheat the saturated steam (see, preheater, steam generator which is the one that produces saturated steam and superheater), which you can do under high pressure, so even when completely spent after passing through the last stage in a turbine, its temperature will remain above the dew point and won't condense into those deadly water droplets. And, since vapor still contains quite some energy once it passes once through a turbine, it goes to a reheater (you can see it labeled so in the diagram) before going to the low pressure turbine, which is the larger one, since by that time the steam would have expanded a lot, and that turbine works more by volume of steam passing through than by pressure.

What is the cheapest for the locality in question and what environmental impacts does it have (as those are typically not included in the economics as they really should be). With regards to global warming, over provisioned solar + wind + storage of various kinds are currently the winners, and the only thing making the transition slower is political hegemonies and corruption. Yes, concentrated solar is one way to achieve storage but not the only one. But don't forget that the full economics equation includes transmission and for home use, it will soon (10 - 20 years) not make economic sense to have transmission wires to the home. Rooftop solar and solar water heaters are already a great solution, but batteries are still a bit on the expensive side although the prices will continue to drop. CSP is a great solution for grid scale power, and we have several CSP plants here in South Africa. It remains to be seen whether they remain competitive with photovoltaics + storage. But the idea that it will single handedly 'solve our energy problem' is nonsense.

Please don't take this the wrong way.  These technologies are amazing and are significantly advancing our understanding of possible solutions for our climate crisis.  However.....  It is extremely frustrating to see YouTube channels providing information to the general public which exposes the positive side of the story and not the negative.  The Ivanpah towers in California are marvels of engineering.  What people are not told is that they do not only produce electricity with solar heat but must also use natural gas (methane) to keep the system operating above a certain temperature at night.  With the most complete data I have for 2015 - 2018, Ivanpah used nearly 1,490,000 MWh of natural gas to produce 126,031 MWh of electricity.  That's about 8.5% efficiency.  Most modern natural gas power plants are CCGT types.  The same amount of natural gas would typically produce about 815,000 MWh of electricity.  That is at 55% efficiency and is 6.4x as much power as Ivanpah.  In those 4 years, Ivanpah would produce approximately 270,000 metric tons of CO2 which would be about the same for a CCGT plant with 6.4x more electricity to show for it.  On another note, hydrogen cars are a perfectly clean way to drive producing only water and heat when burned.  This only works if hydrogen is easy for us to create, which it isn't.  For every 1 metric ton of hydrogen produced, approximately 6 metric tons of CO2 are entering our atmosphere.  Green minded people may say we can capture that CO2 and pump it into deep wells in the ground.  Yes we can but this would add 80 - 90% to production costs.  This is not a realistic scenario.  Once again, great ideas but everyone needs to know both sides of the story.

At 4:52 you said that saturated steam is vapour at high presure that contains also liquid in it. But it is bad to expand in a turbine.
It's really difficult to explain without a couple of mollier diagrams of water, but you can look up for them, specially the T-S one.

When you heat water it starts increasing it's temperature until it reaches(at 1 bar) about 100ºC. This is called saturated liquid, and all the energy you put in went to increase it's sensible heat.
Then, all the energy you put into boiling water doesn't increases the water's temperature, but it's absrobed into transforming liquid water into water vapour, wich is called latent heat. This is due to the vapourization enthalpy, wich is how much energy is required to change the state from liquid to gas.
When all the liquid you had has become vapour, now you are in a state known as saturated vapour, and all of the energy you put in them from now will now increase it's temperature.
The vapour you keep heating is known as superheated vapour, and it will reach temperatures as 650ºC at pressures about 20 bar

If you expand the saturated vapour in a turbine, it will start giving it's latent heat back and condensing, and the water droplets hitting the blades of the turbine will ruin it.
That's why steam turbines work with superheated vapour, wich will give the turbine it's sensible heat but preventing whater to condense inside the turbine.
It is so important to avoid condensation, that steam turbines have multiple stages, and in every one of them expand the superheated vapour to just before reaching the saturated vapour point, and the reheat once or twice the vapour to keep extracting more energy from it before sending it to a condenser stage.
